content.description:
First pitch: make a 4c or 5.8 move to a double bolt belay.

Second pitch: do a 6c or 5.11b/c move (top) to the anchors. It is a nice warm-up. There is moderate climbing before the crux.
content.location: This is on the Lower East Buttress, East of Jungle Gym.  It is a 7 minute approach from our house, versus 3 minute for the Jungle Gym.

content.description:
Dear publisher. My name is Antoine Savelli. My wife and I have lived below the Ophir Wall putting new routes up for 40 years. Access to the lower East Buttress is now closed from our property, indefinitely.

Ophir Arete, as the name implies, has a crux on the second pitch that goes at 5.14a/ 8b. Noteworthy of attention, those who chose the rather chossy leftward crux, that goes at 5.10c.
content.location: It is on the lower, center East Buttress.

content.description:
This is immediately right of the first pitch of

Cosa Nostra

.

It starts on a small bulge, and joins the first belay of

Cosa Nostra

. The crux is at the second bolt, a 6b+ or 5.11b move. At top are two options: finish last 20 feet of

Cosa Nostra

(preferable) or go straight past last bolt using right edge. A double boted anchor is conveniently placed, so a TR can be used for both routes if desired.
content.location: This is on the Lower East Buttress, walking East of the Jungle Gym. It is the easternmost route. Belay on flat rock.

content.description:
P1. 5.9. Slab climb on the left side of the grotto. It is a little runout, and there is loose rock up high where it gets easier. The protection is bolts.

P2. From the anchors, clip a low bolt (chest height), and climb the slab/flared chimney to cracks and up to a big ledge. From the ledge, make a bouldery move (hard clip) to gain the base of the open book/corner system. Make some balancy face moves to gain the arete/corner system with a tough mantel. After the mantel, the last 30+ feet up the arete/corner are superb. Midway up the final arete, you can opt for an easier finish up the left corner system (5.11) or continue direct up the razor edge of the arete on the right (5.12, thin face). The left corner stays a little dirty, but there are good finger locks.
content.protection: 13 clips and two bolt anchor with rap rings.
content.location: Start at the right hand side of the flared chimney/crack system in the middle of the bush gully, 80 feet up at the top of the pillar in the bush gully. You can't see the anchors from the base, but they are in the back of the gully behind the anchors for the central slab routes. The anchors have rap rings. There are multiple options to get up to anchors, the easiest being the far left side slab, or far right side crack (first pitch of The Bush, 5.5). You can also climb any of the routes on the right face (Yellow Jersey, Yorkey's Crumpet, etc.), and rap down to the gully ledge. There are lots of options.

content.description:
The first pitch has a 6b or 5.10d move. It has classic edge granite to a double bolt belay. This belay station shares Midnight in Paris.

The second pitch is 8b+ or 5.14c (lower part): climb to The Treasure Island, leading to golden granite. It has a tenuous beginning and a fantastic and moderate finish. This is a must do. There are double bolt rings.
content.location: This is on the Lower East Buttress, East of Jungle Gym.  It is a 7 minute approach from our house, versus 3 minutes for the Jungle Gym.

content.description:
Pitch 1 is 6b+ or 5.10d, 11a to double bolt belay.

Pitch 2 is 8c+ or 5.15a if one stays dead center under crux bolts (upper section). There is an option to use the right crack, 5.11. Bring small to medium TCUs. Anchor to chains. It has fine rock and tricky sequences.

If one does not use crack, it is hard to onsight red-point. The crack needs some more cleaning if used.
content.location: This is on the Lower East Buttress, East of Jungle Gym. It is a a long 7 minute approach from our house, versus the 3 minute approach for the Jungle Gym. Photos will come later.
